description: These exams retire June 2016. The CompTIA A+ certification is one of the oldest and well-known certifications in the IT world. Obtaining the A+ certification demonstrates that you possess the knowledge and skills of someone who has one year of experience working in a help desk or support role. This is a very valuable certification to have on your résumé, especially for someone just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.
name: A+ 800 Series
subtitle: 800 series

episodes.title: CompTIA A+ Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,322
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,322 --> 00:00:13,269
>> The CompTIA A+ certification is one
of the most well-known certifications

3
00:00:13,269 --> 00:00:16,500
in the IT industry,
if not the most well-known.

4
00:00:16,500 --> 00:00:21,080
It's designed to certify that you
have the equivalent of 6 to 12 months

5
00:00:21,080 --> 00:00:24,490
of field experience supporting
computer hardware and software, right?

6
00:00:24,490 --> 00:00:26,877
It really kind of covers that, that gamut.

7
00:00:26,877 --> 00:00:31,699
The A+ Certification was created a long,
quite a long time ago, back in the,

8
00:00:31,699 --> 00:00:33,891
the 90s, and it was designed to,

9
00:00:33,891 --> 00:00:37,680
to help identify who was
a qualified IT support technician.

10
00:00:37,680 --> 00:00:39,730
If you have somebody come
to work on your computer,

11
00:00:39,730 --> 00:00:43,000
you want to know that they actually
have the skills to work on it.

12
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:48,300
But, because IT was a, a new career field,
there really wasn't a way to do that.

13
00:00:48,300 --> 00:00:49,580
So, CompTIA,

14
00:00:49,580 --> 00:00:54,330
which is the Computer Technology Industry
Association, created this certificate.

15
00:00:54,330 --> 00:00:56,810
The certification program that said,

16
00:00:56,810 --> 00:01:01,370
if somebody's able to pass the exam, that
means they have this amount of knowledge.

17
00:01:01,370 --> 00:01:03,380
They have the equivalent of knowledge,

18
00:01:03,380 --> 00:01:06,830
of somebody who's worked six to 12
months in the field, all right?

19
00:01:06,830 --> 00:01:08,469
Now, how does that affect us?

20
00:01:08,469 --> 00:01:12,958
Well, what it means is if you're new to
IT, if you're just getting started and

21
00:01:12,958 --> 00:01:14,839
you wanna get into IT as a career.

22
00:01:14,839 --> 00:01:18,449
You might have been working with computers
as a hobby or at home for a long time,

23
00:01:18,449 --> 00:01:20,418
you, you might have
a lot of experience but

24
00:01:20,418 --> 00:01:23,300
it's not something you can
put on a resume, right?

25
00:01:23,300 --> 00:01:24,410
I built my own computer so

26
00:01:24,410 --> 00:01:27,830
I could play video games,
well that doesn't look great on a resume.

27
00:01:27,830 --> 00:01:30,932
But if you can say I have
the CompTIA A+ Certification,

28
00:01:30,932 --> 00:01:35,420
now people recognize that you have the
equivalent experience of somebody who's

29
00:01:35,420 --> 00:01:38,260
already got a little bit
of IT work on their resume.

30
00:01:38,260 --> 00:01:41,880
And it's a great way to get your
foot in the door to a new job.

31
00:01:41,880 --> 00:01:45,330
Now, I mention the Computer
Technology Industry Association,

32
00:01:45,330 --> 00:01:47,220
Comp TIA, who are they?

33
00:01:47,220 --> 00:01:52,580
Well, they're a non profit organization
that it basically, built and supported

34
00:01:52,580 --> 00:01:58,120
by their members, and their members
are companies like Microsoft, IBM, Apple.

35
00:01:58,120 --> 00:02:00,760
There's a number of different,
huge, technology companies,

36
00:02:00,760 --> 00:02:02,780
that all contribute to CompTIA.

37
00:02:02,780 --> 00:02:07,422
Because, all of these companies benefit
from having well trained technicians to

38
00:02:07,422 --> 00:02:11,121
either go out in the field to do
warranty repairs and services, or

39
00:02:11,121 --> 00:02:13,900
maybe its the phone support personnel,
right?

40
00:02:13,900 --> 00:02:16,180
People that can answer the phone and
help you through a problem.

41
00:02:16,180 --> 00:02:19,440
They want to make sure that people
meet a basic level of competency,

42
00:02:19,440 --> 00:02:21,160
supporting computers.

43
00:02:21,160 --> 00:02:24,918
Now the CompTIA exam itself has seen
several updates over the years and

44
00:02:24,918 --> 00:02:27,520
it's kinda changed forms a few times.

45
00:02:27,520 --> 00:02:30,571
In its current form,
it's actually two exams.

46
00:02:30,571 --> 00:02:32,842
It's actually been two exams for
a long time, but the, but

47
00:02:32,842 --> 00:02:34,400
the two exams have changed a little bit.

48
00:02:35,430 --> 00:02:40,405
In the new version of the certification,
the first exam focuses mostly on hardware,

49
00:02:40,405 --> 00:02:42,770
so you study hardware based topics.

50
00:02:42,770 --> 00:02:45,405
What each piece of hardware
inside of a computer does,

51
00:02:45,405 --> 00:02:48,360
and how to repair or
troubleshoot and diagnose, those,

52
00:02:48,360 --> 00:02:51,430
those pieces in the event that
one's not working properly.

53
00:02:51,430 --> 00:02:53,920
The second exam is focused
more on the software.

54
00:02:53,920 --> 00:02:57,390
So, how to install an operating system,
how to perform basic tasks,

55
00:02:57,390 --> 00:03:01,860
how to troubleshoot, and identify issues
when you're working with the software.

56
00:03:01,860 --> 00:03:05,580
Now COMPTIA tries to be vendor
neutral with everything.

57
00:03:05,580 --> 00:03:08,180
They try to support as many
vendors as possible, and so

58
00:03:08,180 --> 00:03:13,260
you'll see mentions of Microsoft Windows,
Apple's Mac OS, and

59
00:03:13,260 --> 00:03:16,330
Linux, various Linux
distributions throughout.

60
00:03:16,330 --> 00:03:19,930
But for the most part it's a fairly
Windows-centric certification.

61
00:03:19,930 --> 00:03:23,210
The first exam is hardware so you
really don't deal with OS's at all, but

62
00:03:23,210 --> 00:03:27,080
the second exam does lean a little
more towards Windows because

63
00:03:27,080 --> 00:03:30,540
that's the primary operating system
that's found on most business desktops.

64
00:03:30,540 --> 00:03:34,663
So you need to have a, a little bit more
Windows skill on your resume because

65
00:03:34,663 --> 00:03:37,029
that's whats out there the most, right?

66
00:03:37,029 --> 00:03:40,332
And that may change over time,
and CompTIA changes over time, so

67
00:03:40,332 --> 00:03:42,760
they adapt their exam to reflect that.

68
00:03:42,760 --> 00:03:45,980
The newest version of the exam actually
has some sections of mobile technology,

69
00:03:45,980 --> 00:03:49,350
like cell phones and tablets,
because those are so prevalent and

70
00:03:49,350 --> 00:03:51,700
very few of those actually
run Microsoft Windows.

71
00:03:51,700 --> 00:03:55,904
So, it's, it's kind of neat to see that
certification evolve over the years.

72
00:03:55,904 --> 00:03:58,850
Now, CompTIA A+ holds
a special place in my heart,

73
00:03:58,850 --> 00:04:03,320
because it is the very first IT
certification that I ever got.

74
00:04:03,320 --> 00:04:06,150
I had worked a few odds and
ends, you know, various IT,

75
00:04:06,150 --> 00:04:10,020
kinda, side jobs, but
when I was in college and, and

76
00:04:10,020 --> 00:04:14,150
going through school I decided
I wanted to get into IT.

77
00:04:14,150 --> 00:04:17,160
But I, I didn't have any documented
experience on my resume, and so

78
00:04:17,160 --> 00:04:19,830
I was in the same situation
a lot of you are in today.

79
00:04:19,830 --> 00:04:22,740
I said, well how can I get
an IT job if people don't see

80
00:04:22,740 --> 00:04:26,340
exactly what I've been doing, if they know
that I've actually got that experience?

81
00:04:26,340 --> 00:04:28,290
How do I at least get them to call me for
an interview?

82
00:04:28,290 --> 00:04:30,830
They see my resume,
how am I gonna make them call?

83
00:04:30,830 --> 00:04:35,390
And I went out and I did research and
I learned about the A+, and I studied and

84
00:04:35,390 --> 00:04:38,940
got that certification,
that led t my first hardware support job.

85
00:04:38,940 --> 00:04:41,110
I was doing, warranty repair for
Packard-Bell, and

86
00:04:41,110 --> 00:04:43,980
if any of you guys remember Packard-Bell,
I was really busy.

87
00:04:43,980 --> 00:04:48,470
So that, that was kinda how I started and
then my career just went on from there.

88
00:04:48,470 --> 00:04:50,540
I pursued other certifications and
moved up.

89
00:04:50,540 --> 00:04:52,240
So this is really the ground level for

90
00:04:52,240 --> 00:04:56,300
an IT career, getting started
in IT CompTIA A+ is for you.

91
00:04:56,300 --> 00:04:58,930
If you've already got 15
years of experience, or

92
00:04:58,930 --> 00:05:00,340
20 years of experience working in IT,

93
00:05:00,340 --> 00:05:03,900
you've done all sorts of stuff, you
don't really need the A+ certification.

94
00:05:03,900 --> 00:05:07,720
Unless, unless there is an employer
that absolutely requires it,

95
00:05:07,720 --> 00:05:10,460
you shouldn't do it, you should move
up to a more advanced certification.

96
00:05:10,460 --> 00:05:12,478
Right?
Once you have advanced certifications,

97
00:05:12,478 --> 00:05:15,390
higher end ones, you don't need
the lower end certifications anymore.

98
00:05:15,390 --> 00:05:18,198
So, you can either let them go,
if you already certified, or

99
00:05:18,198 --> 00:05:20,680
you can just skip them and,
and not do them.

100
00:05:20,680 --> 00:05:24,180
But if you're just getting started,
the entry level certifications are a must.

101
00:05:24,180 --> 00:05:27,190
It's what's gonna get that hiring
manager to, to call you for

102
00:05:27,190 --> 00:05:29,130
an interview when they see your resume,
right?

103
00:05:29,130 --> 00:05:30,920
Because your resume might
be light on experience.

104
00:05:30,920 --> 00:05:32,170
That's who this is really designed for.

105
00:05:33,360 --> 00:05:37,110
All right now the A+ certification,
it is a bit of an undertaking,

106
00:05:37,110 --> 00:05:39,280
you've gotta really be ready for this one.

107
00:05:39,280 --> 00:05:43,340
So, if you are certain that moving into
an IT career is what you want to do,

108
00:05:43,340 --> 00:05:44,780
this is your starting point.

109
00:05:44,780 --> 00:05:48,680
If you still haven't made up your mind,
if you're considering a career in IT,

110
00:05:48,680 --> 00:05:52,730
the A+ certification is,
is a little more aggressive than,

111
00:05:52,730 --> 00:05:54,240
than what you probably want to deal with.

112
00:05:54,240 --> 00:05:57,710
So if you're really just testing
the waters, I recommend you go and

113
00:05:57,710 --> 00:06:01,630
take a look at the COMPTIA IT Fundamentals
certification.

114
00:06:01,630 --> 00:06:02,210
All right?

115
00:06:02,210 --> 00:06:04,990
It's a smaller amount of data,
it's a little more entry level, and

116
00:06:04,990 --> 00:06:06,340
it's a lower cost.

117
00:06:06,340 --> 00:06:09,140
It's easier to study for
and easier to attain, and

118
00:06:09,140 --> 00:06:12,100
it'll give you that chance to see if
this is right for you, all right?

119
00:06:12,100 --> 00:06:17,070
If it is great, A+ is your next step,
jump in right here and, and we'll go.

120
00:06:17,070 --> 00:06:20,274
But if you do the IT fundamentals and you
say, you know, this just isn't right for

121
00:06:20,274 --> 00:06:22,780
me I, I,
I don't think IT's the right option.

122
00:06:22,780 --> 00:06:26,300
You can stop right there and
you haven't invested a bunch of time and

123
00:06:26,300 --> 00:06:28,330
money into a certification
that isn't right for you.

124
00:06:28,330 --> 00:06:32,530
So, CompTIA IT Fundamentals is for
people who are on the fence, all right?

125
00:06:32,530 --> 00:06:35,070
But if you know that IT
is what you want and

126
00:06:35,070 --> 00:06:37,393
you just don't have don't have
experience on your resume,

127
00:06:37,393 --> 00:06:40,060
the A+, this is a great place to be,
you're in the right spot.

128
00:06:41,300 --> 00:06:43,740
Now, it's a big undertaking.

129
00:06:43,740 --> 00:06:46,781
The A+ certification covers
more content than any

130
00:06:46,781 --> 00:06:49,759
other certification we've
covered on ITProTV.

131
00:06:49,759 --> 00:06:50,279
All right?

132
00:06:50,279 --> 00:06:53,237
That means there's more episodes,
more content, more data,

133
00:06:53,237 --> 00:06:56,468
more stuff to learn than any of
the other certifications, more than,

134
00:06:56,468 --> 00:06:59,910
than several of the other
certifications combined.

135
00:06:59,910 --> 00:07:02,680
The exam is broken up into two exams, and

136
00:07:02,680 --> 00:07:07,350
each exam has a,
a amount of data that's covered by it

137
00:07:07,350 --> 00:07:10,030
that's equal to just about any other
certification we have on our site.

138
00:07:10,030 --> 00:07:14,750
So, it is a lot and the exams are fairly
expensive, so there is a bit of a cost.

139
00:07:14,750 --> 00:07:19,160
When you go to take these, the combined
cost of the two exams is a little

140
00:07:19,160 --> 00:07:23,890
over $300 U.S., which makes it one of the
more expensive certifications to attain.

141
00:07:23,890 --> 00:07:26,380
But, it's got a lot of value,
it's got a lot of recognition, and

142
00:07:26,380 --> 00:07:28,220
it's a great certification to get.

143
00:07:28,220 --> 00:07:28,800
All right?

144
00:07:28,800 --> 00:07:34,850
I got my A+ certification in 1999, so 15,
oh almost 16 years ago, but 15 years ago.

145
00:07:34,850 --> 00:07:37,910
And that was a, a,
a great start to my career back then,

146
00:07:37,910 --> 00:07:42,990
got me moving forward, and really did help
with moving into those advanced areas.

147
00:07:42,990 --> 00:07:47,583
And, and for you guys it kind of works
the same, it is a great starting point.

148
00:07:47,583 --> 00:07:51,595
Now, the A+ certification is
a expiring certification, and

149
00:07:51,595 --> 00:07:56,140
what that means is every two years
your certification will expire, and

150
00:07:56,140 --> 00:07:58,958
when that happens you've got two choices.

151
00:07:58,958 --> 00:08:03,633
Either one, you take the exam again,
and that keeps it up to date and

152
00:08:03,633 --> 00:08:07,917
now you're renewed, or two,
you do continuing education.

153
00:08:07,917 --> 00:08:11,417
With CompTIA they expect you
to keep learning, don't stop.

154
00:08:11,417 --> 00:08:14,793
Once you get your A+ certification, you
should then be looking at the next thing.

155
00:08:14,793 --> 00:08:18,820
Maybe you wanna go for the Microsoft MCSA
or maybe you wanna do the Cisco CCENT or

156
00:08:18,820 --> 00:08:21,140
maybe you wanna do Network+, Security+,

157
00:08:21,140 --> 00:08:24,008
whatever you start looking
at other certifications and

158
00:08:24,008 --> 00:08:28,030
that continues your education and
keeps your A+ current, all right?

159
00:08:28,030 --> 00:08:29,190
But if you ever stop.

160
00:08:29,190 --> 00:08:31,310
Sit back and just rest on your laurels and
say, you know what?

161
00:08:31,310 --> 00:08:32,710
I got my job, I'm good.

162
00:08:32,710 --> 00:08:35,050
I'm not gonna do any more studying.

163
00:08:35,050 --> 00:08:38,850
Well, after two years,
your A+ certification will expire and

164
00:08:38,850 --> 00:08:41,250
you'll no longer have
a current certification.

165
00:08:41,250 --> 00:08:43,270
You can still say, yes I was A+ certified.

166
00:08:43,270 --> 00:08:44,230
I passed that exam.

167
00:08:44,230 --> 00:08:44,770
You can say that.

168
00:08:44,770 --> 00:08:46,320
That's, that's perfectly fine.

169
00:08:46,320 --> 00:08:49,950
But your no longer current, and that means
that the exam you took back then might

170
00:08:49,950 --> 00:08:51,698
have been based on older technology.

171
00:08:51,698 --> 00:08:55,900
Mine, that I took and I, you know,
I I took the exam way back in 1999.

172
00:08:55,900 --> 00:08:59,778
My exam covered Windows 95 and
some Windows 3.1, I had a lot of old

173
00:08:59,778 --> 00:09:03,722
technology that was on that exam
because that was out there at the time,

174
00:09:03,722 --> 00:09:06,180
there was still people
using it at the time.

175
00:09:06,180 --> 00:09:10,378
And today its not like that right
those nobody runs Windows 95 or

176
00:09:10,378 --> 00:09:12,069
Windows 3.1 anymore.

177
00:09:12,069 --> 00:09:15,130
So the knowledge gets outdated and
that's why you've got to keep it current.

178
00:09:15,130 --> 00:09:18,130
That's why CompTIA has
the expiring rotation.

179
00:09:18,130 --> 00:09:20,850
Well, that, that and
it's an ANSI certified certification.

180
00:09:20,850 --> 00:09:23,570
And in order to be ANSI certified
you have to do continuing education,

181
00:09:23,570 --> 00:09:25,600
that's part of the, the rules.

182
00:09:25,600 --> 00:09:27,910
All right, so if you wanna get certified,

183
00:09:27,910 --> 00:09:30,460
well it's a good idea to learn
a little bit about the certification.

184
00:09:30,460 --> 00:09:32,630
So let's take a look at CompTIA's webpage.

185
00:09:32,630 --> 00:09:35,760
CompTIA has a ton of certifications.

186
00:09:35,760 --> 00:09:41,100
If you go to certification.comptia.org you
can pull up their list right here under

187
00:09:41,100 --> 00:09:45,620
Get Certified and they have a whole list
of all these different certifications.

188
00:09:45,620 --> 00:09:47,850
Most of them are very specialized.

189
00:09:47,850 --> 00:09:51,330
And A+ is where you want to start, right?

190
00:09:51,330 --> 00:09:53,333
The A+ certification itself, well,

191
00:09:53,333 --> 00:09:56,500
they just kind of layout exactly
what I said a few moments ago.

192
00:09:56,500 --> 00:10:00,720
It's ANSI certified, certifies
the 6 to 12 months of experience.

193
00:10:00,720 --> 00:10:03,760
It's available for IT support technicians,
administrators, specialists and

194
00:10:03,760 --> 00:10:05,150
those different job roles.

195
00:10:05,150 --> 00:10:08,820
Very flexible, you know, in,
in it's very well known.

196
00:10:08,820 --> 00:10:12,240
But what they don't mention immediately
here is that it is two different exams and

197
00:10:12,240 --> 00:10:13,380
so we'll see that right down here.

198
00:10:13,380 --> 00:10:14,460
Required exams.

199
00:10:14,460 --> 00:10:19,610
There's the 220-801, which is the one
that's software I mean, hardware centric.

200
00:10:19,610 --> 00:10:23,500
And then there's the 220-802 that's
the one that is software centric.

201
00:10:23,500 --> 00:10:28,630
If you're going out and buying books to
study with, make sure that they're for

202
00:10:28,630 --> 00:10:31,180
the 220-801 and 802,
that's the most current version.

203
00:10:31,180 --> 00:10:32,660
There have been previous versions and

204
00:10:32,660 --> 00:10:35,500
so if you find a book that's on sale,
a lot of times it'll be for

205
00:10:35,500 --> 00:10:39,110
one of the older version of the exams and
it might not get you ready for the exam.

206
00:10:39,110 --> 00:10:40,530
It might be fine, it might not.

207
00:10:40,530 --> 00:10:42,524
You, you kinda take that risk.

208
00:10:42,524 --> 00:10:46,617
Now each exam is performance based, so
when you do the exam you'll have multiple

209
00:10:46,617 --> 00:10:49,567
choice questions, but
you'll also have simulations and

210
00:10:49,567 --> 00:10:52,879
what they call hotspot questions
where they show you a picture and

211
00:10:52,879 --> 00:10:56,030
you have to click on something
based on the question.

212
00:10:56,030 --> 00:11:00,740
So it's fairly interactive and
questions are weighted differently, and

213
00:11:00,740 --> 00:11:05,000
that means no two people
have the exact same exam and

214
00:11:05,000 --> 00:11:07,640
they may have a very differing
amount of questions.

215
00:11:07,640 --> 00:11:10,530
So they tell us that it's
a maximum of 90 questions.

216
00:11:10,530 --> 00:11:12,804
I've heard of people having
as few as 40 questions.

217
00:11:12,804 --> 00:11:15,452
It just depends on which
questions you draw there,

218
00:11:15,452 --> 00:11:18,593
there randomly pulled from this pool of,
of questions, and

219
00:11:18,593 --> 00:11:22,940
if you're getting a lot of high point
questions you'll have less of them.

220
00:11:22,940 --> 00:11:25,230
But if you have a lot of low point

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don deal with the major instructions that allow the computer to power on and start the computer's operating system. They talk about and show several different BIOS configurations and how an A+ technician would change the settings if needed.
episodes.title: BIOS Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take brief look at components on a motherboard. They describe the most common components and what they do for the computer. Using a motherboard, they show the common expansion slots to give more functionality to the computer system.
episodes.title: Motherboard Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don break down the various types of RAM found in modern computers. They also take a little trip down memory lane to see how the current standards evolved. They wrap up the show by discussing some of the special features available for RAM used in servers and high-end workstations.
episodes.title: RAM Types and Features

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don describe some of the common expansion cards available for desktop computers. They also review some of the expansion ports found on standard mother boards. They wrap up discussing which expansion slots are ideal for certain scenarios.
episodes.title: Expansion Cards

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine storage devices used in common computers. They take a look at optical, solid-state, floppy and tape based media. This is part one of a two part series.
episodes.title: Storage Devices and Media

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at magnetic storage used in common computers. They examine IDE, SATA and SCSI technologies and wrap up the show discussing RAID. This is part 2 of a two part series.
episodes.title: Storage Devices and Media Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don introduce PC processing.  They describe the function of CPU (Central Processing Unit) and talk about the most popular physical interfaces an A+ certified professional is likely to see in PCs they support.  They also talk about some of the different choices for cooling the CPU in the PC too.
episodes.title: CPU Types and Cooling

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don cover the assorted cable interfaces found on modern PCs. They cover storage, human input, video and other connectors and their physical characteristics.
episodes.title: Connection Interfaces

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don cover the basic function of a computer power supply unit (PSU). They describe the assorted cable connectors found on most power supplies as well as the physical form factors. They wrap up the show describing how to calculate the wattage your equipment requires to ensure your power supply is able to provide adequate power levels.
episodes.title: Power Supplies

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don describe the specialized hardware used to support custom PC configurations. They take a look at editing workstations like graphics, video and CAD editing machines. They also describe specialized requirements for other non-standard configurations.
episodes.title: Custom PC Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at the different types of display devices available for computing.  They talk about the difference in technology and how to choose the best type for the needs of a user.
episodes.title: Display Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don make sure we can visually identify and describe some of the most popular connectors used when connecting peripherals and display devices with cables. They emphasize the pins, shape and gender of the connectors.
episodes.title: Cables and Connectors

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don conclude their discussion on cables and connectors. They cover USB, FireWire, PS/2 and other various  cables. This is the second part of a two part series.
episodes.title: Cables and Connectors Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel walk you through installing and configuring a plethora of different peripheral devices. From keyboards to touch screens; from digital cameras to gamepads, they explain to you the ins and outs of many commonly connected devices.
episodes.title: Peripheral Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a closer look into the most popular types of cables used in networking.  Today, networking media is dominated by fiber optics and twisted pair cabling.  In the past, coaxial cables would have been in that landscape.  An A+ technician should be able to identify visually and be able to describe these cables.
episodes.title: Network Connectors

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie tackle the 3 different types of cables and their respective connectors used in computer networking and that are covered in the A+ exam; fiber optic, twisted pair, and coaxial. Watch as Daniel and Ronnie explain how each of these technologies work and how they are connected.
episodes.title: Connectors and Cabling

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie give you an in-depth look into the world of TCP/IP. With a focus on the IP side of TCP/IP, Daniel and Ronnie explain how the Internet Protocol handles addresses for each of our network hosts. Starting with binary conversion they take you step by step with the inter-workings of subnet masks, IP classes and their ranges, the two most common IP versions, and the services that make IP administration possible.
episodes.title: TCP/IP Properties

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the common TCP and UDP ports and protocols that you'll encounter on your A+ exam. They cover port numbers and their associated protocols/applications and even demonstrate how to use some of them in a practical way. Telnet, FTP, SSH, SMTP, SNMP and many more are covered explored in this show.
episodes.title: TCP/UDP Ports and Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at configuring a SOHO router. They discuss settings such media access control (MAC) filtering and the various wireless channels.
episodes.title: Configuring a SOHO Router

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take you on a journey through the myriad of different Internet connection types and their distinctions. Internet connection types covered in this segment include Cable, DSL, Dial-up, Fiber, and Satellite. Dan and Ronnie cover each of these types in-depth to help you prepare for the A+ exam.
episodes.title: Internet Connection Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish out explaining the different Internet connections types set forth in the A+ exam. They talk in-depth about technologies such as ISDN, Cellular, and WiMax touching on the advantages and disadvantages of each.
episodes.title: Internet Connection Types Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the various types of networks, like LAN, MAN, PAN, and WAN, and network topologies such as Bus, Ring, Star, Mesh, and Hybrid.
episodes.title: Network Connection Types

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don show and describe the most common network devices that an A+ IT Technician may encounter. They also talk about their function within a network briefly. The devices include routers, switches, VoIP Phones, firewalls, modems, wireless access points and others.
episodes.title: Network Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel walk you through the many different tools used by network technicians. They explain in great detail common tools like crimpers, toner probes, and punchdown tools, going into the use and even showing them in action.
episodes.title: Network Tools

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at laptop hardware and components. They look at some legacy hardware such as PCMCIA and Express cards. They offer a hands-on demo of the inside components of a laptop with a full tear-down of a laptop.
episodes.title: Laptop Hardware

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don discuss the properties of laptop displays. They disassemble a laptop display to show examples of its backlight, inverter and antennas.
episodes.title: Laptop Displays

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don discuss various laptop features. They take a look at a handful of function keys such as brightness and volume keys. They also show examples of docking stations and compare them to port replicators. They wrap up with discussion on physical cable locks.
episodes.title: Laptop Features

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe the different printer types that you might encounter as a technician. This segment focuses in on Laser Printers; both the printers components and their functions, then moves on to the Laser Printer print process.
episodes.title: Printer Types and Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe the different printer types that you might encounter as a technician. This segment covers printer types such as Inkjet/BubbleJet, Thermal, and Impact Printers. They take you through each of the various printer types components and their associated functions for printing.
episodes.title: Printer Types and Processes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore and explain how to install and configure a print device. They talk about the different wired and wireless technologies for connecting printers as well as the different print drivers that you might encounter.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Printers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie, talk about the different maintenance methods and tools for the various printer types. They explain how to replace toner cartridges, print heads, ink ribbons, and even paper. Then they discuss appropriate cleaning methods to keep your printers sparkling and print jobs smudge free.
episodes.title: Printer Maintenance

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over appropriate safety procedures for working with electronic components. They describe how to discharge static electricity using ESD straps and mats so as not to damage any of our PC's internals. They also discuss personal safety to avoid personal injury. They explain proper lifting techniques, how to avoid tripping hazards, and even proper disposal of hazardous materials.
episodes.title: Safety Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the different environmental and safety concerns when dealing with hazardous materials as well as the different environmental controls that are in place for maintaining a safe work place and data/equipment preservation.
episodes.title: Environmental Factors

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain why proper communication and professionalism is important. In great detail they cover topics like how to properly interact with your end users, building rapport, dealing with difficult users, and meeting expectations.
episodes.title: Professionalism

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the proper procedure for dealing with prohibited content or activity. They give you the ins and outs of making sure that you identify what policy has been violated, effectively collecting the evidence, and maintaining it for actions that may be taken.
episodes.title: Dealing with Prohibited Content

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don compare and contrast features of XP, Vista and Windows 7. They talk about and demonstrate most of the features available on Windows operating systems. They also talk about the hardware requirements for installing operating systems.
episodes.title: Microsoft Operating Systems

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain how to install and configure the Windows 7 Operating System (OS). They show you how to prepare for an install from choosing the type of installation you'll need to perform, (upgrade, clean install, stand-alone, side-by-side), through finishing the install by applying software updates and finding, downloading, and installing drivers for hardware.
episodes.title: Installing an Operating System

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Daniel walk through using different command line tools and their basic operation. They cover networking command line tools such as PING, IPCONFIG, TRACERT, and NETSTAT. Also discussed OS command line tools TASKLIST, TASKKILL, and SHUTDOWN.
episodes.title: Command Line Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel continue covering command line tools, specifically OS tools that will allow you to work with the file system. They show how to create and remove files and directories using MD, RD and DEL. Also shown are file system administrative tools like FDISK, FORMAT, and DISKPART as well as troubleshooting tools like SFC and CHKDSK.
episodes.title: Command Line Tools Part 2

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie start to explain the use of the Computer
Management console, where they create, manage, and modify user and group accounts. They also describe how the Device manager can be used for troubleshooting issues with hardware in, or attached to a PC.
episodes.title: OS Features and Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain and demonstrate some of the built-in security tools for the Windows operating system. They cover user account policies for passwords and lockouts, as well as local computer policies for auditing, user rights, and security. They also cover system tools such as the Task Scheduler, Services, System Configuration tool, Component services, and Data Sources.
episodes.title: OS Features and Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring the different operating system features and tools. They specifically cover Print Management; which allows for adding, removing, managing, and troubleshooting print devices. They walk you through checking for issues with a PC's physical memory using the Windows Memory Diagnostic tool. Other tools covered are the Windows Firewall which is used for securing connections to and from a PC; the System Configuration utility (MSCONFIG) for managing system boot options, services, and startup programs; and lastly the Windows Task Manager to assess system performance, work with running tasks, and processes.
episodes.title: OS Features and Tools Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish out the objectives of Operating System Features and Tools. They demonstrate how to use the Disk Management tool in the Windows 7 OS to mount new drives, work with partitions, and configure the different arrays (Spanned, Striped, Mirrored). They explain the different migration tools that enable you to bring over fiels and settings from old PCs to new ones. Finally they give an overview of the many different Run Line tools like MSCONFIG, MMC, and DXDIAG.
episodes.title: OS Features and Tools Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain in detail the different utilities found in the Control Panel (using "Classic View/Large Icons") of the Windows operating systems. They specifically explain the Internet Options from top to bottom. They walk you through each one of the tabs and show you how to set a home page, set up parental controls, and even reset Internet Explorer when things have gone awry.
episodes.title: Control Panel Utilities

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue through the plethora of Control Panel Utilities and their functions such as Display/Display Settings, Folder Options, Windows Firewall, and Power Options.
episodes.title: Control Panel Utilities Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Ronnie, explain the unique control panel utilities found in Windows XP, Vista, and Windows 7 operating systems. You'll see that each of these operating systems, while similar, have some very unique utilities or naming conventions for utilities in their respective Control Panels.
episodes.title: Control Panel Utilities Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the details of setting up and configuring the Windows operating system for networking. They take you from the basics of PC networking to the details of the Windows 7 OS network settings. Explained are the different types of networks that Windows 7 recognizes (Home, Public, Work, Domain) and the different connection methods for getting network access (wired, wireless, cellular). IP addressing will be given particular attention to give you a good foundation of understanding.
episodes.title: Windows Client Networking

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the best practices for preventive maintenance procedures using the built-in Windows operating system tools as well as 3rd party applications. They will walk you through the different types of backups (Full/Differential/Incremental), scheduling maintenance tasks (checking disks for errors and updating software like drivers, antivirus, and firmware), and employing system tools like system restore, CHKDSK, and creating a recovery disk.
episodes.title: Preventive Maintenance

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the built-in security inherent to the Windows 7 operating system. You'll learn how certain default users and group are used to grant and deny access; the same with file and share permissions. They also cover network share security, permission inheritance, and user authentication using Single Sign On.
episodes.title: OS Security Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics and benefits of employing virtualization on a desktop client. They cover everything from purpose to network and resource requirements as well as security.
episodes.title: Client-side Virtualization

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Mike cover common prevention methods which is technical jargon for “keeping the bad guys out.” They take a look at some of the security threats that are out there and how to protect yourself from them.
episodes.title: Common Prevention Methods

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at some of the common security threats available today. They discuss threats such as social engineering, malware vs spyware, and rootkits.
episodes.title: Common Security Threats

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at securing a basic workstation. They discuss best practices such as creating strong passwords and restricting user permissions. They also talk about disabling unused accounts and disabling autorun.
episodes.title: Securing a Workstation

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie talk about how to dispose of data that may still exist on hard drives.  Depending on the sensitivity of the data and if we are re-purposing the media.  We may choose: formatting, sanitization or outright destruction.
episodes.title: Data Disposal Methods

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look into securing a SOHO wireless network.  They show the most common settings any A+ technicians should be familiar with to help secure the wireless access to the network.
episodes.title: Securing SOHO Wireless

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie talk about securing a SOHO wired network.  It's easy to forget that network security should also include making sure that wired devices such as PCs, switches, wireless routers, and cabling.  So Mike and Ronnie talk about some of the simple things that can make a wired network more secured.
episodes.title: Securing a SOHO Wired Network

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics of mobile devices and their operating systems. They will take you through the differences and similarities between Android and Apple's iOS. They will also explain the concept of Open Source vs. proprietary, or closed-source software. Other topics discussed include the actual technology built into the devices; things like screen orientation, screen touch technologies, and even GPS/Geotracking.
episodes.title: Mobile Devices OSs

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over how to connect to different types of networks using mobile devices. They explain the differences between, cellular, wireless, and bluetooth technologies as well as demonstrate how to connect to each one respectively. Also covered is how to connect email accounts once a network connection has been established.
episodes.title: Mobile Networking and Email

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the different methods for securing mobile devices. They cover all the basics like passcodes, lock screens, and even antivirus solutions. They also cover some more advanced security measures like remote wiping, device locators, and taking backups of the device in case of theft or permanent loss.
episodes.title: Securing Mobile Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore the hardware differences between mobile devices like tablets and other mobile devices like laptops and notebooks. They talk about what field serviceable parts and how newer mobile devices are no longer open to field repair and/or upgrade. They also cover the topic of multi-touch and gestures that expand that capability. Lastly, SSD hard drives are shown to be the drive of choice when it comes to mobile devices due to their ruggedness and performance.
episodes.title: Mobile Hardware Differences

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over what synchronization is with regards to mobile devices and the different types of data that you can sync. They'll explain the features of iTunes for Apple mobile devices and even sync apps for Android users. Also covered are the types of connections you can use to sync your devices (Wired and Wireless)
episodes.title: Mobile Synchronization

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss troubleshooting theory and best practices. They explain the necessity of formulating a solid plan of attack using a systematic, logical approach and take you through each of the necessary steps the will ultimately lead to a solution. They also talk about how to effectively work with end users so that they can help you help them.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Theory

episodes.description: In this segment, our resident fire marshals, aka Daniel and Ronnie, inform you on what to do when you see and/or smell the burning badness coming from your computer.
episodes.title: Smoke and Burning Smells

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over random hardware failures that are common in computers. Topics covered are unexpected or random computer shutdowns, device failures, and power issues. Also covered is what to make of the indicator lights found on most computers and peripheral devices.
episodes.title: System Lockups

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie talk about the different sounds, both normal and not so normal, that can emanate from your PC. After explaining the good from the bad, they explain what can be the culprit behind the bad noises and what you can do when you're hearing them.
episodes.title: PC Noises

episodes.description: POST beeps, and lockups, and resets! Oh, my! In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through troubleshooting a variety of different problems that plague our computers; specifically system lockup, POST beeps, and BIOS setting resets.
episodes.title: POST Beeps

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie direct you on how to handle issue with your PC when things heat up. They show you the different methods for keeping it cool inside a computer and show you some methods to employ when those methods break down. So keep a cool head and enjoy this segment on overheating.
episodes.title: Overheating

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie explain proper procedure when experiencing an issue where your computer is trying to boot to the wrong device. This might be an install CD accidentally left in a CD-ROM drive, or maybe an incorrect boot sequence. Whatever the cause, Daniel and Ronnie hope to help fix what is ailing you.
episodes.title: Booting to Incorrect Device

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate what you can do when experiencing the dreaded Blue Screen of Death, or BSOD. They show you the BSOD and explain how hardware failures are one of their common causes, as well as how to troubleshoot and solve the issue.
episodes.title: BSOD

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie go over issues that commonly cause boot issues. They talk about causes and solutions for when you are experiencing problems like continuous reboots, blank screen at bootup, or even no power.
episodes.title: Boot Issues

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate and explain some of the common tools used when troubleshooting hardware issues. If you've ever wanted to know how to test a power supply using a multimeter, then this show is for you!
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explore and explain many of the common problems with motherboards, RAM, CPU, and power. They walk you through each of the different issues and talk about how to troubleshoot and resolve the issue using the appropriate tools.
episodes.title: Common Motherboard Issues

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through troubleshooting common failure specific to hard drives. Physical problems with hard drives can cause a myriad of issues so here our resident experts equip you with the knowledge to handle problems like read/write failures, slow performance, and even annoying noises.
episodes.title: Common Hard Drive Failures

episodes.description: In this segment, Dan and Ronnie explain what to do when you encounter a boot failure or the Blue Screen of Death, aka the BSOD. They cover what physical components may be causing the issue as well as how to fix your Master Boot Record using command line tools.
episodes.title: Boot Failure and BSOD

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate the different tools, both physical and software, used to troubleshoot and repair failing hard drives. Screwdriver kits and external hard drive enclosures are key components in any technician's toolbox and working knowledge of hard drive specific command line tools is a must. So watch as Daniel and Ronnie give you the rundown on how to properly employ each tool.
episodes.title: Hard Drive Repair Tools

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Ronnie talk about the different types of RAID and what to do when your RAID configuration encounters a problem. They show you how to create and delete a RAID array within the BIOS of a motherboard that has a built-in hardware RAID controller and describe symptoms of a failing controller.
episodes.title: Broken RAID Array

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel takes you through each one of the A+ objectives for troubleshooting common video and display issues. Whether it be CRTs or LCDs, VGA or DVI, if you're preparing for the A+ exam you're going to be expected to know video issues inside and out. Topics covered include VGA mode, dim and/or flickering image, dead/stuck pixels, and even degaussing.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Display Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explore the world of network troubleshooting. They cover problems like network connectivity, common network service failure, and the tools necessary to get network connectivity back on track.
episodes.title: Network Troubleshooting

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain what to do when encountering common problems that can plague the Windows operating system. Here in Part I, they go over issues like spontaneous restarts, missing dll errors, and even the dreaded blue screen of death!
episodes.title: Troubleshooting OS Problems

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel finish discussing common problems that can plague an operating system and how to remedy those problems. They also talk about some of the common software tools used by technicians for correcting a myriad of OS problems.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting OS Problems Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to troubleshoot and avoid many common security issues. They explain what to do when experiencing problems like spam, slow performance, security alerts, and even rogue antivirus.
episodes.title: Common Security Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to troubleshoot and avoid many common security issues. They round out the bases of the common security issues covered in this objective; problems like disappearing files, hijacked email, and denied access to files. They they show you how to use the tools of the trade to fix and clean an infected computer as well as the best practices that follow.
episodes.title: Common Security Issues Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie cover common laptop issues. They explain what kind of symptoms may be expected and then how to troubleshoot and repair those problems. They cover topics like display issues, networking/wireless connectivity, and power problems.
episodes.title: Common Laptop Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie cover troubleshooting printers. Printers are one of the most common peripherals and will require the attention of an A+ tech at some point in their life. Watch as Daniel and Ronnie walk you through a plethora of common issues and explain what to do to correct them. Whether it be paper jams, distorted printouts, or the printer just won't print, they've got all the bases covered.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Printers
